College of Chemical Engineering Sichuan University Chengdu Sichuan 610065 PR China Graphical abstract Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst prepared by a one-step urea hydrolysis method was tested in the dry reforming of methane (DRM) reaction at medium temperature. The catalyst was characterized by H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, XRD, XPS, TGA, Raman, and TEM. On Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst, the catalytic activity increased with time on stream, while a decrease was observed on Ni–ZrOx catalyst. In order to understand this phenomenon, the catalysts were characterized at pre-reaction and during reaction for different time on stream such as 100 min, 300 min, and 480 min. According to the XPS results, it was shown that the Zr species on Ni–ZrOx were reduced during the reaction, whereas the Zr species was almost in equilibrium on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst. In combining the results of XRD and activity in DRM, we can conclude that a stable ZrO2 structure on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst might promote the redox of nickel species during the reaction, and further promote the redistribution of nickel species. However, on the Ni-ZrOx catalyst, the unstable ZrO2 support might result in a decrease of surface nickel content while an increase of Ni particle size, thus led to a decrease of activity for DRM. Keywords Dry reforming of methane Manganese Stable ZrO2 Redistribution CO2 1 Introduction It is well known that CH4 and CO2, greenhouse gases, come mostly from anthropogenic production, and their emissions are responsible for global warming. The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) announced that the concentration of heat-trapping greenhouse gases (CO2) in the atmosphere has reached new record (407.8 ppm in 2018 for CO2). While in 2011, the atmospheric concentration of CO2 and CH4 was 393.1 and 1.8 ppm, respectively. It means the increase of CO2 concentration in the atmosphere year-by-year, leading to more and more extreme climates. The global warming potential (GWP) of methane is about 28–36 times higher than that of CO2, which also causes a serious Earth's radiative imbalance [1–3]. Thus, the process of CO2 reforming of methane (DRM) is becoming an interesting strategy to convert two greenhouse gases into value-added products, such as syngas [4,5]. The noble metal-based catalysts exhibited high activity, stability, and selectivity almost without carbon deposition, such as Rh, Ru, and Pt [6–10]. However, nickel-based catalysts would be a more suitable choice for the DRM reaction, because of the comparable activity, stability, and selectivity to noble metal catalysts [5,11,12]. Unfortunately, carbon formation and sintering of nickel are two major problems for Ni-based catalysts [13,14]. The former could derived from the CH4 decomposition (Eq. 1), CO disproportionation (Eq. 2) and the reverse carbon gasification reaction (Eq. 3) [13,15]. Thermodynamically, Eq. (1) tends to occur at high temperature and low pressure, while the other two Eqs. (2) and (3) are favoured at low temperature and high pressure. Herein, the DRM reaction is processed under high temperature with an atmosphere, thus the coke usually comes from the Eq. (1). (1) C H 4 → C + 2 H 2 Δ H ° 298 K = 75 k J · m o l - 1 (2) 2 C O → C + C O 2 Δ H ° 298 K = - 172 k J · m o l - 1 (3) C O + H 2 → C + H 2 O Δ H ° 298 K = - 131 k J · m o l - 1 Recently, ZrO2 has received huge attention as a promoter and/or support in the dry reforming of methane, due to its high carbon resistance [10,16–18]. Lou et al. [19] designed a Ni/ZrO2 with 1.1 nm nickel particle diameter, which exhibited outstanding stability in the DRM reaction with very little carbon deposition after reaction. Because small nickel particles could result in more interface of Ni-O-Zr, which could promote carbon removal. Katsutoshi et al. [17] compared Pt/ZrO2 and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts for the carbon deposition over the DRM reaction. They found that more carbon was deposited on the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, which would cover the Pt particles, thereby resulting in the deactivation of Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. While carbon hardly formed on Pt/ZrO2 catalyst. Dębek et al. [18] and Swirk et al. [20] showed that ZrO2 as promoter could increase the basicity of Ni–Mg–Al hydrotalcite-derived catalysts, thereby enhance the adsorption of CO2 to promote the elimination of carbon, in agreement with the results reported by Pompeo et al. [21]. Besides, the structural properties, such as thermal and mechanical stability, particle size, and crystal phase are very important for reforming reactions [16,22–25]. Xu et al. [24] reported that the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst with the smaller size of ZrO2 exhibited higher stability for dry reforming of methane than the one with a bigger particle size of ZrO2 (>25 nm). The Ni/am-ZrO2 catalyst (amorphous) exhibited the highest activity and stability for the DRM reaction than Ni/t-ZrO2 (tetragonal) and Ni/m-ZrO2 (Monoclinic) catalysts, which was reported by Zhang et al. [25]. It is well known that manganese has a high oxygen storage capacity and the suppression agglomeration of metal species under the reduction condition at high temperatures [16,26]. Wang et al. [27] reported that the improved catalytic performance of the Co-Ce-Zr-Ox catalyst modified by Mn was mainly attributed to the increase of oxygen mobility and the surface oxygen species. Because of the higher amount of mobile oxygen, the coke on the surface could be easily oxidized to COx on the Mn-promoted Co-Ce-Zr-Ox catalyst. Yao et al. [28] and Seok et al. [29] found Mn could enhance the dispersion of Ni and the less carbon deposition through resisting the aggregation of metallic nickel species. Özkara-Aydınoğlu et al. [22] noticed that the addition of Mn could reduce carbon deposition with a decrease in catalytic activity. A similar phenomenon has been reported by Luna et al. [4] and Liu et al. [30]. On Mn-promoted catalysts, we found that the activity increased with time on stream. In order to understand this phenomenon and the effect of Mn on the activity for DRM, Ni–ZrOx and Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalysts prepared by a one-step synthesis method were compared and characterized after different time on stream of DRM. The relationships between the catalytic performance and surface properties of Ni–ZrOx and Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalysts were discussed along with the influence of the reaction time on the catalytic behavior. 2 Experiment 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ni–ZrOx and Ni–Mn–ZrOx materials were prepared by the urea hydrolysis method (one-step synthesis) according to our previous work [31]. For Ni-ZrOx material, 7.06 g urea (Sigma-Aldrich), 1.14 g nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Emsure), 7.96 g of Pluronic P123 (Sigma-Aldrich) amphiphilic block copolymer, and 5.03 g zirconium (IV) oxynitrate hydrate (Sigma-Aldrich) were dissolved in distilled water. The synthesis mixture for Ni-Mn-ZrOx material containing the same amounts of reactants plus 0.93 g Manganese (II) nitrate tetrahydrate (Sigma-Aldrich) (corresponding to a loading of 10 wt %). In both cases, a light blue precipitate was formed at 95 °C with constant stirring for 48 h. Then, the obtained precipitate was aged at 100 °C for 24 h. Thereafter, the slurry was isolated by filtration, washed by a small amount of distilled water, and then placed at room temperature. Last, these two precipitates were calcined in flowing air at 800 °C for 5 h (heating rate of 1 °C/min). The obtained materials were denoted as Ni–ZrOx and Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalysts. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The reducibility of catalysts was obtained by the temperature-programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR). The H2-TPR profiles were conducted on a BELCAT-M (BEL Japan, BEL Europe GmbH, Krefeld, Germany) apparatus, equipped with a TCD. The calcined catalysts were pretreated at 150 °C under a helium atmosphere for 30 min. Then the catalysts were reduced under 5% H2/Ar mixture flow. The catalysts were heated to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min and held on 30 min at 900 °C. The data collected from 100 to 900 °C. The basicity of catalysts was measured based on the temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) on the same equipment. The catalysts were reduced at 700 °C under a 5% H2/Ar flow for 60 min. CO2 was adsorbed at 80 °C for 60 min under a mixture flow of 10 % CO2/He. Afterward, the weakly adsorbed CO2 was cleaned by helium flow for 30 min. Last, the catalysts were heated to 900 °C (10 °C/min) under a He flow. The data collected from 80 to 900 °C. The acidity of reduced catalysts was measured using temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) method on the same equipment. Prior to the test, the sample (60 mg) was reduced, then cooled down to 50 °C under He flow. Then, NH3 was adsorbed under 10 % NH3/He flow for 60 min. After cleaning the weakly adsorbed NH3 on the surface of the sample for 30 min, the material was heated from 50 °C to 900 °C under He flow with 10 °C/min heating rate. The crystal structure of catalysts was obtained by X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements. The XRD patterns were recorded by a DX-1000 CSC diffractometer with a Cu Kα radiation source. The anode current and voltage were 25 mA and 40 kV, respectively. The diffraction patterns were recorded in a range of 10° < 2θ < 80°, with a scan step size of 0.03° and a scan speed of 0.3 s step−1. The crystal particle size on catalysts was calculated by using the Scherrer Equation. The surface composition was studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements. The spectra were recorded on an AXIS Ultra DLD (KRATOS) spectrometer instrument with monochromated Al radiation. All of the data (the electron binding energy) were referenced to the C1s peak at 284.6 eV [32]. Quantitative analysis of the surface composition was determined by the peak areas and the element-specific Scofield factors. The morphology of catalysts was obtained by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) on an FEI Tecnai G2 20 Twin instrument with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The carbon deposition of spent catalysts was characterized by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The sample weight was about 10 mg. Then, the sample was heated from room temperature to 800 °C under airflow with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. The weight of the sample (and the weight loss) was recorded from room temperature to 800 °C. The properties of the carbon deposited on our samples were studied by Raman spectroscopy measurements on an objective (X50LWD) with a Laser of 532.17 nm, a Filter of D1, a Grating of 600 g/mm, and a Hole of 200 μm. The data were collected over the range of 40 − 4000 cm−1. The physical property of catalysts was evaluated by nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms method by using a Belsorp Mini II apparatus (BEL Japan) instrument. Before measurement, the calcined catalyst was degassed under vacuum condition at 200 °C for 2 h. Then the test was carried out at −196 °C. The surface area of the sample was calculated according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and the pore volume and pore diameter were calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. 2.3 Catalytic activity in DRM at 700 °C The carbon dioxide reforming of methane activity test was carried out in a fixed-bed flow microreactor at atmospheric pressure. The sample temperature of each test was monitored by a K-type thermocouple contacted with the catalytic bed. Prior to reaction, the sample was in situ reduced at 700 °C for 60 min under the flow of 5 vol% H2/Ar. The total flow rate was 100 mL/min. After reduction, the sample was cleaned by argon. The mixed feedstock gases (CO2 = 10 mL/min, CH4 = 10 mL/min, and Ar = 80 mL/min) were introduced to the catalyst bed with the total gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) values of 48,000 h−1. The outlet gases (Feedstock and product gases) were detected by a gas micro chromatography (490 Varian), equipped with a TCD detector. The respective conversions of CH4 ( X C H 4 ) and CO2 ( X C O 2 ), and the H2/CO molar ratio were calculated as follows: (1) X C H 4 = n C H 4 , i n - n C H 4 , o u t n C H 4 , i n × 100 % (2) X C O 2 = n C O 2 , i n - n C O 2 , o u t n C O 2 , i n × 100 % (3) H 2 / C O = n H 2 , o u t / n C O , o u t 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The reducibility of catalysts Fig. 1 presents the H2-TPR results of calcined samples. According to our previous works [31], the peak at about 400 °C on the Ni-ZrOx catalyst was attributed to the reduction of NiO species with weak interaction between Ni and Zr. The main reduction peak (600 °C) came from the reduction of NiO species with strong interaction between Ni and Zr, and the ZrO2 species. The last peak at 850 °C was also assigned to the reduction of ZrO2 species. The introduction of the Mn promoter resulted in the reduction properties of Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst. A new weak peak between 200−400 °C was assigned to the reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3 [30,33]. A wide peak between 400−700 °C corresponded to the reduction of NiO species, Mn2O3, and ZrO2 [30,31,33]. Thus, the reduction peaks shifted to lower temperatures area on the Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst. A similar observation was reported in literature [14,27,28]. These shifts implied that the interaction between Ni and support on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst was relatively weaker than that on Ni–ZrOx catalyst, which might result in the sintering of nickel on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst [34,35]. 3.2 The basicity of catalysts Fig. 2 (A) shows the CO2-TPD plots of the reduced catalysts. In agreement with the literature [35], the three desorption peaks on Ni–ZrOx catalyst centered at 159, 249, and 395 °C were attributed respectively for weak, medium, and strong basic sites [36,37]. The weak basic site is mainly consisted of weak Brønsted basic sites such as surface OH groups, the medium-strength basic sites consists of Lewis base sites such as unsaturated (cus) O2− and Zr4+–O2− centers, and the strong basic sites corresponds the CO2 adsorption of the cus Zr4+ centers with strong Lewis acidity [38,39]. Whereas, the desorption peaks on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst shifted to low temperature. The three peaks shifted to 140, 232, and 375 °C for weak, medium, and strong basic sites, respectively. According to Table 1 , Mn promoted the formation of weak basic sites and decreased the content of strong basic sites. The amount of weak and medium-strength basic sites on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst increased from 15 and 43 μmol CO2/g to 34 and 48 μmol CO2/g, respectively. Besides, the total basic sites increased from 73 to 92 μmol CO2/g by the introduction of Mn. Generally, the medium-strength basic sites might contribute to the carbon removal, because the CO2 adsorbed on those medium-strength basic sites and then formed to monodentate and bidentate carbonates species, which promoted the carbon removal [38,40,41]. The H2/CO2 temperature program reaction experiment was carried out by Takano et al. and the authors found that the CO2 desorption occurred below 250 °C. Thus the CO2 adsorbed on the weak basic sites was less reactive with H2, due to the weak adsorption of CO2 [40]. Therefore, the weak basic sites might inhibit the reverse water-gas shift reaction (RWGS), thus CO2 reacts with carbon more than H2 during the reaction [35,40,42]. Thus, weak and medium-strength basic sites promote the elimination of carbon deposition, which corresponds to the result reported by the literature [3,31,43,44]. The NH3-TPD profiles is reported in Fig. 2. Ammonia desorption occurred at temperatures between 50 and 450 °C. A wide composite desorption peak was obtained, which could be deconvoluted into three contributions. Each one of these contributions corresponds to weak, medium-strength and strong acid sites, depending on desorption temperature as attributed in literature [45,46]. The peaks shifted to higher desorption temperatures on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst. In other words, the presence of Mn seems to enhance the acidity of the catalyst. The deconvolution results of the NH3-TPD profiles are presented in Table 2 . The total acidity on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst was 446 μmol NH3/g, which was lower than those on Ni–ZrOx catalyst (486 μmol NH3/g). Besides, both Ni–Mn–ZrOx and Ni–ZrOx catalysts presented mainly weak-medium acid sites. The strong acid sites was considered important in the activation of hydrocarbons, thus, the Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst with more strong acid sites would promote the direct methane decomposition reaction [47]. 3.3 The physical property of catalysts The results are shown in Table 2 and Fig. 3 . All the shapes of the isotherms were assigned to the type IV isotherm with the H3 type of adsorption hysteresis [48]. Compared with the Ni–Mn–ZrOx, the adsorption hysteresis on the Ni–ZrOx catalyst could be observed more evident, which corresponded with the results of pore size distribution. The pore diameter on Ni–Mn–ZrOx and Ni–ZrOx catalysts almost distributed at about 2 nm. Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst exhibits lower surface area of 103 m2/g, whereas surface area increases obviously to 113 m2/g for the Ni–ZrOx catalyst. Thus, compared to the Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst, the Ni-ZrOx catalyst exhibited a better physical structure. 3.4 Catalytic activity in dry reforming of methane The results of the activity test are presented in Fig. 4 and Table 3 . It was shown that the initial conversions of CO2 and CH4 on Ni–ZrOx catalyst were about 90.2 and 90.5 %, respectively, which were slightly higher than those obtained on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst (85.4 % and 84.6 % for CO2 and CH4 conversion, respectively). It was worth noting that CH4 conversion on Ni–ZrOx catalyst decreased to 84.0 % after reaction for 100 min TOS (time on stream). Then it decreased a little bit after reaction for 300 min TOS, and finally, it stabilized at 82.0 %. The CO2 conversion and the H2/CO ratio showed a similar trend. The CO2 conversion slowly decreased to 82.9 %. And the H2/CO decreased from 1.07 to 0.98 within the first 100 min TOS and to 0.97 after 300 min TOS. On the contrary, for Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst, the CH4 conversion slowly increased to 95.8 % within 300 min. Similar phenomena could be observed in CO2 conversion and H2/CO ratio. After reaction for 300 min TOS, the CH4 conversion, CO2 conversion and H2/CO ratio on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst almost stabilized at 97.1 %, 93.5 % and 0.96, respectively. Last, the conversions of CO2 and CH4 on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst were higher than those on Ni–ZrOx catalyst at the end of the reaction. Besides, the CH4 conversion was higher than the CO2 conversion, indicating that the side reaction direct methane decomposition (CH4 → C+H2) occurred on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst, which would result in carbon deposition. Similar results had been reported by Dębek [49]. Meanwhile, the ratio of H2/CO on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst was lower than unity, indicating that the occurrence of the reverse water–gas shift reaction [42,50,51]. In order to understand the increase activity within 300 min, catalysts were charactered by XPS and XRD after reduction (before starting the reaction), and after reaction for 100 min, 300 min, and 480 min TOS. 3.5 X-rays photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis It is assumed that methane could be dissociated on the nickel-metal site, while CO2 could be adsorbed and activated on nickel-metal sites and/or support [52]. Thus, the physicochemical properties of nickel metal and support are directly linked to the performance of the catalyst. In order to analyze the Ni and Zr at the surface of the catalysts, XPS experiments were conducted for the above samples versus TOS. Fig. 5 (A) and (B) present the Zr 3d results. The Zr 3d binding energies on Ni–ZrOx catalyst shift to lower values with the time on stream. While it keeps on almost the original states over Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst. This shift may explain the fact that the Zr species could be reduced during the DRM reaction. According to the literature, the Zr 3d peak can be deconvoluted into several peaks [53,54]. The peaks at about 182.3 eV, 181.4 eV, 180.5 eV and 179.3 eV are attributed to the Zr4+, Zr3+, Zr2+ and Zr1+, respectively [31,55,56]. The percentage of each peak is listed in Table 4 . In the beginning of the reaction, on Ni–ZrOx catalyst, the percentage of Zr4+ and Zr3+ was about 12 and 88 %, respectively. While about 73 % of surface Zr species were reduced to Zr2+ on Ni–ZrOx catalyst after reaction for 100 min TOS. The Zr1+ species could be observed after reaction for 480 min TOS. This indicated that the Zr species on Ni–ZrOx catalyst were reduced during the reaction. It is well known that the Zr cations in ZrO2 are very difficult to be reduced [56,57]. Herein, the Zr4+ species were gradually reduced to Zr1+, indicating that this material has high oxygen mobility, like TiO2 [58]. However, unlike the redox cycle between Ti2+ and Ti3+, the Zr4+ species were reduced during the reaction, which might affect the stability of the ZrO2 structure under reaction conditions. On the contrary, for Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst, the initial percentage of Zr4+ and Zr3+ was about 15.7 % and 84.3 %, respectively. The percentage of Zr4+ and Zr3+ species after 300 min reaction was about 20 % and 80 %, respectively. And after 480 min TOS, it was found about 22 % and 78 % for Zr4+ and Zr3+ species. Herein, the Zr4+ species might be reduced by H2, CH4 and CO, however, the Zr3+ might be oxidized by CO2. Thus, the Zr species on Ni–Mn–ZrOx was almost in equilibrium. In conclusion, Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst exhibited a more stable structure for ZrO2 species during DRM at 700 °C. That more stable ZrO2 might play a key role in the formation and/or the stabilization of the Ni° species during the DRM reaction. Fig. 6 (A) and (B) present the results of Ni 2p3/2 profiles for Ni–ZrOx and Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalysts. According to the literature [59,60], the obtained curve of Ni 2p spectra could be deconvoluted in three peaks. The peaks centered at about 852.3 eV, 855 eV, and 861 eV are assigned to Ni° species, Ni2+ species, and satellite, respectively [42,61]. And the percentage of Ni° species from XPS analysis was listed in Table 4. The percentage of surface Ni° species on Ni–ZrOx and Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalysts at the initiation of the reaction was about 24.4 and 20.0 % respectively. This is in agreement with the fact that Ni–ZrOx catalyst exhibits higher initial activity than the one on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst. It was worth noting that the percentage of NiO species was higher than that of Ni° species at the initiation of both catalysts. The higher content of NiO species might be oxidized by air/CO2 or CO2/CO be adsorbed on Ni°, which was explained elsewhere [31,62]. The percentage of surface Ni° species on the two catalysts displayed an opposite trend with time on stream. On Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst, the percentage of Ni° species increased to 40.0 % after 100 min TOS, then it decreased to 23.2 % after 300 min reaction and to 22.6 % after reaction for 480 min TOS. Those observations indicated that part of Ni2+ species was reduced by CH4, H2, or CO to Ni° species during the first 100 min, while part of Ni° species was oxidized by CO2 after reaction up to 300 min TOS. Ni° species would be oxidized by CO2 to form NiO species, while the NiO species would be reduced by CH4, CO and/or H2 to Ni° species. Thus, the redox of nickel species would happen under the redox atmosphere [63,64]. Meanwhile, the stable Zr species on Mn-promoted catalyst may promote the redox of nickel species under redox atmosphere, which may promote the redistribution of nickel species [31,63,64]. On the contrary, for Ni–ZrOx catalyst, the percentage of Ni° species decreased to 17.4 % after 100 min TOS, to 12.9 % after reaction for 300 min, and it slightly increased to 13.3 % at the end of the reaction. Herein, the Ni° species were almost oxidized by CO2 during the reaction, which might assign to the reduction of Zr species on the Ni-ZrOx catalyst. Fig. 7 presents the Mn 2p profiles of XPS experiment. The peaks of Mn 2p was deconvoluted into three pairs of peaks, and the B.E. peaks of Mn 2p2/3 at 641.5, 642.4 and 644.6 eV were attributed to Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+ species, respectively [65,66]. The content of each state of Mn species listed in Table 4. After reduction, the content of Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+ species on the surface of the Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst was 66.8, 22.4 and 10.8 %, respectively. While after reaction for 100 min, the Mn2+ species were mainly transformed into Mn3+ and Mn4+ species. Then the Mn3+ and Mn4+ species were reduced to Mn2+ after reaction for 300 min. At the end of the reaction, the Mn2+ species were oxidized to Mn3+ and Mn4+ species. This oxidation-reduction process of Mn species might promote the redox of nickel species and further improve the redistribution of nickel species. 3.6 Ni crystallite size and dispersion XRD results after different time on stream are reported in Fig. 8 . The reflection peaks at 30.5, 35.3, 51.0, 60.5, and 74.9° can be attributed to the tetragonal phase of ZrO2. Another peak at about 44.5° corresponded to the most intense peak of the Ni° phase [67]. The tetragonal phase of zirconium oxide (ZrO2) was evidenced in all the catalysts. No monoclinic ZrO2 and NiO phases were detected in these catalysts. Significantly, the Ni° reflection plane (2θ = 44.5°) on Ni–ZrOx catalyst shifted to bigger Bragg angles after reaction for 100 min, while it shifted to smaller Bragg angles after reaction for 300 min. The maximum shift distance for Ni° was about 0.22° during the reaction. For Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst, the swing became gentler. The shift slightly decreased (0.07°). Except for the Bragg angles, the d-spacing of Ni° plane on Ni–ZrOx catalyst shrunk from 2.04 Å to 2.03 Å, while d-spacing of ZrO2 (2θ = 30.4°) reflection plane increased from 2.94 Å to 2.95 Å. In our previous work [35], it is about 2.96 Å on Ni/ZrO2 catalyst that prepared by traditional impregnation method without NiO-ZrO2 solid solution. Because the radius of Ni2+ ion (0.78 Å) is smaller than that of Zr4+ ion (0.84 Å), thus the lattice parameter of ZrO2 would shrink after the substitute of same of zirconium sites by nickel. On the contrary, the expansion of ZrO2 manifested that some nickel was set free from the skeleton of the ZrO2 phase [51]. Thus, For Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst, the d-spacing of the Ni° plane kept to 2.03 Å. Those phenomena indicated that the crystal structure of nickel species and zirconium species was more stable on the Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst [28,29,68]. Yao et al. [28] reported the addition of Mn could enhance the interaction between Ni and support by the formation of NiMn2O4. Besides, some manganese oxide species MnOx can cover the nickel particles, thereby inhibiting the sintering of nickel species, as already reported by Seok et al. [68]. Both of those effects could limit the aggregation and migration of metal Ni. The crystallite sizes of both catalysts calculated from the Scherrer equation were presented in Table 5 . The Ni metal particle size on Ni–ZrOx catalyst increased from 12 to 22 nm after reaction for 100 min, manifesting severe sintering on Ni–ZrOx catalyst in the first 100 min of the reaction, and then leading to the decrease of activity in DRM within reaction for 100 min TOS. On the contrary, for Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst, the crystallite size of Ni° decreased from 29 to 18 nm after 100 min TOS, then increased to 25 nm at 300 min TOS and to 24 nm after 480 min TOS, corresponding to an increase in the DRM activity up to 97 % after 300 min in DRM. This fact implies that the redispersion of Ni° species occurred on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst, which attributed the redox of nickel species under the condition of continuous alternating reduction and oxidation [31,64,69]. This redispersion could promote the formation of smaller crystallite size of Ni° species, which improve the activity for DRM. Similar result was reported by Li et al. [70]. The authors found that Mn could improve the dispersion of nickel and enhanced the interaction between nickel and support during the dry reforming of methane, and further improved the catalytic performance of Mn-modified catalyst. 3.7 Carbon deposition after DRM According to the XRD results, a peak corresponding to carbon graphite could be observed on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst after reaction for 300 min with the carbon graphite’s crystallite size of 20 nm. While after 480 min TOS, the crystallite size of carbon decreased to 14 nm. Besides, the carbon deposition of both catalysts after for 480 min TOS was analyzed by the means of TGA, Raman spectroscopy, and TEM. The results are presented in Fig. 9 . Generally, the presence of Zr could promote the adsorption and/or activation of CO2, thereby decreasing the carbon deposition in the DRM process [18,50]. Mn could avoid carbon deposition or lead to its suppression as reported by Yao et al. [28] and Seok et al. [29], due to the formation of smaller Ni particle size on Mn-modified catalyst since small Ni particles showed better resistance against coke formation [71]. Generally, the Mn promoter could reduce the carbon deposition [22,28,30]. However, herein, the carbon deposition (5.3 %) on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst was higher than that on catalyst Ni–ZrOx catalyst (3.7 %). This can be first explained by a higher conversion observed after 480 min TOS on promoted Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst. The CO2 conversion was lower than the CH4 conversion. Thus, the rate of carbon elimination was lower than the rate of carbon accumulation, leading to more carbon nanotube formation on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst. Similar results had been reported by Yu et al. [72], and the authors also found the Mn-promoted Ni-based catalyst (0.038 gc·gcat −1) exhibited higher carbon deposition on non-promoted Ni-based catalyst (0.0244 gc·gcat −1) in DRM reaction. Secondly, according to the XRD results, the particle with the size greater than 20 nm on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst led to catalytic selectivity towards methane cracking (Eq. (1)), and further caused carbon deposition [31,73,74]. Meanwhile, the occurrence of the reverse water–gas shift reaction would result in carbon deposition since part of CO2 would react with H2, which corresponded to the results reported by Luna et al. [4]. They also mentioned that the Ni-Mn catalyst (250 mgc·gcat −1) showed higher carbon deposition in DRM reaction than that on Ni catalyst (60 mgc·gcat −1). From the TGA results, the carbon on both catalysts might be the same type, because the mass loss observed at the same temperatures. Furthermore, in order to understand the nature of carbon deposition, Raman spectroscopy experiments were carried out, as shown in Fig. 9(B). Two peaks could be observed on both catalysts after reaction. D band and G band were ascribed to the disorder and graphite of carbon materials, respectively [42,75,76]. The ID and IG represented the intensity of the D band and G band, respectively. The ratio of IG/ID was related to the crystalline degree of the carbon materials. According to our previous work, it was about 1.7 on Ni–ZrOx catalyst [31]. However, it was found at 2.0 on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst, indicating that the coke exhibited a higher crystalline degree. The morphology of the deposited carbon was characterized by the TEM experiment, as presented in Fig. 9(C) and (D). It was observed that carbon nanotubes formed on both catalysts after reaction for 480 min. And more carbon nanotubes were observed on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalysts, which was in agreement with both results of TAG and Raman analyses. Besides, a similar distribution of nickel particles could be observed on both catalysts, almost at 15−20 nm, which corresponded to the XRD results. 4 Conclusions The DRM activity test was carried out at 700 °C for 8 h, with a GSHV of 48,000 h−1. In the beginning, the nickel particles on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst (29 nm) were found bigger than that on Ni–ZrOx catalyst (12 nm), which was attributed to a weaker interaction between Ni and support. Thus, Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst exhibited lower initial activity for the DRM reaction. However, these two catalysts exhibited an opposite trend in CH4 and CO2 conversions, and the ratio of H2/CO during the 700 °C DRM process. On Ni–ZrOx catalyst, the activity decreased with TOS since the content of surface Ni° decreased and the Ni° particle size increased, which was assigned to the non-stable structure of ZrO2. Because the Zr species was reduced during the DRM process and part of Zr species even reduced to Zr1+ after reaction for 480 min TOS. On the contrary, on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst, the Zr species do not change during TOS. This stable ZrO2 might contribute to the redox of nickel species and further to the redistribution of nickel species, which promotes the formation of smaller crystallite size of Ni° species for DRM, thereby enhancing the activity up to 300 min TOS. Thus, the stable structure of ZrO2 might play a key role in the active site for dry reforming of methane. coredata.dc:description: Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst prepared by a one-step urea hydrolysis method was tested in the dry reforming of methane (DRM) reaction at medium temperature. The catalyst was characterized by H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, XRD, XPS, TGA, Raman, and TEM. On Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst, the catalytic activity increased with time on stream, while a decrease was observed on Ni–ZrOx catalyst. In order to understand this phenomenon, the catalysts were characterized at pre-reaction and during reaction for different time on stream such as 100 min, 300 min, and 480 min. According to the XPS results, it was shown that the Zr species on Ni–ZrOx were reduced during the reaction, whereas the Zr species was almost in equilibrium on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst. In combining the results of XRD and activity in DRM, we can conclude that a stable ZrO2 structure on Ni–Mn–ZrOx catalyst might promote the redox of nickel species during the reaction, and further promote the redistribution of nickel species. However, on the Ni-ZrOx catalyst, the unstable ZrO2 support might result in a decrease of surface nickel content while an increase of Ni particle size, thus led to a decrease of activity for DRM.
coredata.dc:title: Dry reforming of methane over Ni–ZrOx catalysts doped by manganese: On the effect of the stability of the structure during time on stream
